Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometer for Interdisciplinary Research and Undergraduate Research Training
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) Program, Westminster College will acquire an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). This instrument is used to analyze samples especially to determine the presence of metals and their concentrations. It operates by creating an energetic hot plasma that vaporizes the sample and produces ions. The ions of interest emit spectral fingerprints (emission spectra) enabling their identification and concentration. This is a widely used instrument for analysis of environmental samples (water, soil, waste, etc.). The instrument will be used by undergraduate students in research and in laboratory training courses. It will also be used in research by students at Allegheny College and Thiel College. High school students at the Wilmington Area High School will use the instrument to continue and expand ongoing efforts to monitor heavy metal contamination in local water sources. Westminster College will further its goal of providing the most current instrumentation needed for research and training in Chemistry, Biology, Physics, Environmental Science, and Material Science and expanding regional STEM research and training capabilities.

The proposal is aimed at enhancing research especially in areas including (a) developing methods to synthesize commercially-relevant rare earth silicates; (b) recoverying rare earth oxides from scrap and end-of-life tech products; (c) recoverying manganese from passive water treatment systems; (d) using chemometrics to predict metal concentrations in frack water; (e) analyzing environmental stressors on aquatic vertebrates; (f) quantifying nutrient availability in forest soils receiving chronic nitrogen amendments; and (g) measuring metal contamination in compost.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Westminster College used the awarded funds to purchase an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) with an autosampler. This equipment has been used for ongoing and new research projects at Westminster College and Allegheny College, as well as for science outreach to area high school students. The users of the ICP-OES have been enabled to conduct leading-edge materials analysis and environmental chemistry research supporting the overall objective of Westminster College to increase STEM research and education broadly throughout the western Pennsylvania and eastern Ohio.

 

Intellectual Merit: The acquisition of the ICP-OES has furthered the development of methods for the recovery of rare earth oxides from scrap and end-of-life tech products; the recovery of manganese from passive water treatment systems; the use of chemometrics to analyze ICP-OES data; the quantification of nutrient availability in forest soils receiving chronic N amendments; and the measurement of geochemical tracers in groundwater flow. The ICP-OES was also used by nearby high school students to continue and expand ongoing efforts to monitor heavy metal contamination in local water sources. This research not only addresses significant environmental issues that impact western Pennsylvania, it also provides hands-on experiences that have been shown to enhance STEM learning and student engagement.

 

Broader Impacts: In addition to seven faculty users (five at Westminster College and two at Allegheny College), 63 unique undergraduate STEM students were extensively trained as users of the ICP-OES. This training included method development, sample preparation, data collection and analysis, and troubleshooting. These students and faculty have made a total of 12 presentations of research data generated using the ICP-OES at national scientific conferences. An additional 16 research presentations using data from the ICP-OES have been made at local and regional meetings. Of the 63 undergraduate student users, 21 have graduated with 11 working in the STEM industry and five continuing their education in STEM graduate school (the remaining 5 students are pursuing advanced professional degrees in healthcare). Additionally, 88 area high school students had hands-on, real-world research experiences using the ICP-OES. By providing access to state-of-the-art scientific instrumentation to high school students, Westminster College is widening the pipeline for students interested in studying and pursuing careers in a STEM field.
